Description: Fragment of shoulder of East Greek pottery closed vase with root of large, probably horizontal handle; interior reserved; black glazed outside with tail and rear of body of a feline in added white to right; white line above added red area at lower break.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Aphrodite (Naukratis) (probably, as referred to by Gardner 1888, 47)
Curator's comments: Compare British Museum 1888,0601.678.a-d (of thicker fabric). Gardner 1888, 47, makes special note of the find of 'very few' examples, all in very bad condition, of this 'peculiar' class of pottery (i.e. with painted decoration in white on a black glaze) in the Aphrodite sanctuary. He notes the occurrence of both animal and plant designs. Clay analysis with NAA by Hans Mommsen of this piece (sample Nauk 88) remains difficult to interpret; a possible Attic provenance (Mommsen et al. 2012, 440) can probably be discounted in favour of East Greek, notably Chian production, with the chemical composition of the fabric close to Chian pottery (close to chemical group ChiA, cf. Kerschner and Mommsen 2009, 134). Mommsen, H., Schlotzhauer, U., Villing, A. and Weber, S. 2012, ‘Herkunftsbestimmung von archaischen Scherben aus Naukratis und Tell Defenneh durch Neutronenaktivierungsanalyse’, in Schlotzhauer and Weber 2012, 433–55. Kerschner, M. and Mommsen, H., ‘Imports of East Greek pottery to Sicily and Sicilian productions of East Greek type. Archaeomoetric analyses of finds from the votive deposit in Katane’, in A. Pautasso 2009, Stipe votiva del santuario di Demetra a Catania. La Ceramica greco-orientale, Studi e materiali di archeologia greca 9, Catania, 125–50
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer & Villing 2006 / East Greek Pottery from Naukratis: The Current State of Research (p. 55. Table 1, Nauk 88)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2220)
